A corporate website is hosted on several Amazon EC2 instances across multiple regions around the globe.
How should an Administrator configure the website to maintain high availability with minimal downtime if one of the regions has network connectivity congestion for an extended period of time?

choices.A: Create an Elastic Load Balancer in front of all the Amazon EC2 instances.
choices.B: Create an Elastic Load Balancer that fails over to the secondary site when the primary site is not reachable.
choices.D: Create an Amazon Route 53 latency Based Routing Record Set that resolves to Elastic Load Balancers I each region and has the Evaluate Target Health flag set to ג€trueג€.
choices.C: Create an Amazon Route 53 Latency Based Routing Record Set that resolves to an Elastic Load Balancer in each region. Set an appropriate health check on each ELB.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
For both latency alias records, you set the value of Evaluate Target Health to Yes. This causes Route 53 to determine whether there are any healthy resources in a region before trying to route traffic there. If not, Route 53 chooses a healthy resource in the other region.

https://docs.aws.amazon.com/Route53/latest/DeveloperGuide/dns-failover-complex-configs.html

Selected Answer: C
By using Amazon Route 53's Latency Based Routing (LBR), the Administrator can configure a record set that directs traffic to the ELB in the region with the lowest latency. This allows users to be automatically routed to the region with the best performance.

Additionally, setting up health checks on each ELB ensures that if one region experiences network connectivity issues or becomes unavailable, Route 53 will route traffic to the ELB in a different region with better connectivity.
